hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![2 rows of cookies. Row 1 has 3 cookies. Row 2 has 3 cookies. A vertical dotted line divides the cookies into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![2 columns of cookies. Column 1 has 3 cookies. Column 2 has 2 cookies. A horizontal dotted line divides the cookies into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs with 1 extra cookie.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\blueE{16}$ bananas.

![4 rows of bananas. Each row has 4 bananas. A horizontal dotted line divides the bananas into groups of 2 rows and a vertical dotted line divides the bananas into 4 columns so there are 8 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9385229cbd986eaedbd5c5bec0435fba9a5fa261)

Each banana has a pair, so there are an even number of bananas.

In this image, there are $\blueE{12}$ bananas.

![2 rows of bananas. Each row has 6 bananas. A vertical dotted line divides the bananas into 6 columns so there are 6 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5a9fe351c0396f4231eea4952168e146c21c95c5)

Each banana has a pair, so there are an even number of bananas.

In this image, there are $\maroonD7$ bananas.

![2 rows of bananas. Row 1 has 3 bananas and Row 2 has 4 bananas.  A vertical dotted line divides the bananas into 4 columns so there are 3 pairs with 1 extra banana.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9b71cc2c3715401cd05ebff6775cd68472c43352)

Each banana does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of bananas.

This image shows an odd number of bananas:

![2 rows of bananas. Row 1 has 3 bananas. Row 2 has 4 bananas.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/47870d4e644f901011ca4758d35bf3696150cd25)

question.content:
**Which image shows an odd number of bananas?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![4 rows of bananas. Each row has 4 bananas.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ff227dffa161e51d82807c1a9e28ba38f471cb75)
![2 rows of bananas. Row 1 has 3 bananas. Row 2 has 4 bananas.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/47870d4e644f901011ca4758d35bf3696150cd25)
![2 rows of bananas.Row 1 has 6 bananas. Row 2 has 6 bananas.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9bdb45ec7b0df420c63d649c1869646914e9c441)
